data.title: Depressing
data.text: The food was not good at all, barely edible.  Service was cold, unwelcoming.  Atmosphere cold and uncomfortable on a cold night.  We were sorry we bothered to come here and left hungry.

data.title: Not bad, not as good as it used to be
data.text: I started eating at the Plearn when it was by the University Theater, it moved along the way.  We had the Po Tak , the fisherman's soup, it used to be served more spicy and it was a good idea to get rice with it but , also the papaya salad used to be served hotter and was good to have rice with it, and we had a vegetarian with cashews dish the three together were good but not as good as they used to be.

data.title: Excellent Thai food
data.text: This restaurant moved from up the block, maybe 3 years ago, and was sold. The new owners have a very good lunch crowd, and less so at dinner time. The food is very good and the prices reasonable. They stay open on holidays such as Xmas and New Years eve. They have a very good lunch combo with many inexpensive choices. This is  good food!

data.title: Tasty food, friendly service, affordable prices.
data.text: This place isn't fancy but the food is great, the service is frindly and the prices are easy on your wallet. If you are in the mood for good Thai food this is a great choice.

data.title: Excellent Thai Cuisine for Decades
data.text: One of my go-to restaurants for Thai as a Cal student, Plearn is still as tasty today as it was 30 years ago. You can't go wrong with standard Thai fare, such as Mee Krob to start, Thom Ka Gai with chicken for soup and Chicken Panang (ask for it with white meat chicken). If you like a little kick to your food, ask for your dishes to be prepared a little spicier, as the tendency is to serve dishes milder by default. The three dishes I've suggested are more than enough for two people. Chase it with Thai iced tea/coffee to cool down your mouth. Very reasonably priced. Despite the glutton of Thai choices in the East Bay, you're unlikely to find much better than Plearn.

data.title: Just delicious authentic Thai
data.text: I recently attended a weekend workshop a block away from this place and I ate here three times, twice for lunch and once for  dinner.  The place isn't much to look at and it doesn't accept credit cards, but everything I had was good in that way that wakes up your mouth and has you say "oh that's the way this is supposed to taste!" The spicy eggplant dish, with pork and prawns was probably my favorite thing, but the pat thai (that's how they spell it) was lovely, the red curry with duck was tasty and I really liked the spicy seafood. I stay away from carbs but the brown rice that came optionally was worth breaking my diet.

data.title: DECENT THAI ON UNIV AVENUE
data.text: Fine --will come back and review this more fully. Plearn has been around for ages but many other places have eclipsed this place for overall flavor and freshness, I'm afraid

data.title: Classic Bay Area Thai Restaurant
data.text: My benchmark Thai restaurant. Back when I lived in Oakland, in the late 90s, I would take BART up to Berkeley for a meal at the "old" Plearn at every opportunity. On a recent visit to downtown Berkeley for the first time in at least ten years (during which I've eaten at many, many Thai restaurants that failed to live up to Plearn's standard), I and five companions had lunch the "new" Plearn, just down University from its previous location. I felt some trepidation, only partially allayed by the positive reviews here on Yelp, as to whether the place could possibly have stood the test of time and relocation without going seriously downhill, but I'm happy to say that the food is every bit as good as it used to be. The pork kang kew wan (green curry) was rich and complex, spicy but not overpowering hot. The pumpkin curry was the hit of the evening - a perfect balance of sweet, savory, and spicy. And the iced tea and coffee are still the best around.  And it's still inexpensive - the bill for six people came to about $65 including tax. Highly, highly recommended.

data.title: food is still good, comming here for years, friendly service as usual

data.title: Tried the walnut creek location. Love the food, service and location in WC.

data.title: PLEARN: FAKE THAI FOOD GIVES DIARRHEA!
data.text:
I have read so many "rave" reviews about this place that we had to see what it was all about. FYI: Just because an eatery has a good write-up doesn't mean anything because it is common knowledge that restaurants "pay" (read bribe) reviewers to turn in a good review by offering to place ads in their rag. Anyhow, we wanted to give Plearn Thai(pronounced "PLUN") a chance and try it with a neutral attitude. 

Here are my notes:

1. Service: Quite slow. 
2. Bad attitude: The owner's wife is the manager of the kitchen and you can hear her yelling in her Chinese-Thai dialect (Bangkokian Central Thai with a TaiChiew accent) and scolding her hispanic busboys. The owner and matre-D, a Chinese Thai male was quite nice. We saw the owner seat an aquaintance in the most desireable seat and then his wife blew a fuse and yelled at the owner to re-seat them in a less desireable seat. Wow, talk about inner conflict within a restaurant.
3. Food: Fake. Phony Thai. They have some made-up dishes to trick the "White folks" who don't know any better. For example, the Pad Grapao chicken tastes nothing like the real Thai dish. Instead, they added MALAYSIAN Curry into the dish!! What!?!? I've never heard of this or seen this dish anywhere in SF, LA, or Bangkok. Clearly, this restaurant is successful at pulling the wool over the public's eyes.  The Tom Yum Goong soup tastes like it was made from a package, lacking a fresh flavor. The Thai Iced Tea was nothing more than sugar water. Some dish that pretended to be Chicken Larb was quite tasty though. 
4. After Effects: My Thai wife who ate with me had a bad case of DIARRHEA within 20 mins of eating at Plearn. I don't know what to say. It could have been from the Tom Yum Goong soup or the Pad Grapao chicken dish.

In conclusion, I would not go there again. I would catergorize it as just another phony Thai restaurant who caters to the ignorant non-Thais.
